original_prompt: In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonX wants what is mentioned in the Tail or not. In this task, wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonX, respectively. As a result of PersonX giving PersonY gifts, PersonX may also desire to hug PersonY. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
generated_prompts: Given two phrases, Head and Tail, separated by <sep>, you have to determine if PersonX wants what is mentioned in the Tail as a result of the Head event. In this task, wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonX. The phrase may contain a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action. Classify your answers into "Yes" or "No".

In this task, you will be given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and Tail are short phrases that may include participants, but the names of the participants have been replaced by generic words such as PersonX, PersonY, and PersonZ. PersonX is always the subject of the event in the phrase. You need to determine if PersonX has a postcondition desire for what is mentioned in the Tail as a result of the Head. This desire can be any kind of desire, such as wanting to hug PersonY if PersonX has given PersonY gifts. Classify your answers into "Yes" or "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can represent an object, a person, and/or an action.
